bibl.note: This is a letter dated June 13, 1837 from from Thomas Moore to his cousin James King. In the letter, Moore expresses his distress over the death of his sister's husband, and worry for her future. He also expresses concern over his cotton crop, that is hindered by drought. He also writes in his letter that the Bank has suspended specie payment, and he is unsure when it will resume.

div.opener:
T. Thomas O. Moore 1837
Col Colonel James M King Murfreesboro Tennessee
Mail 25
postmark: Jun 20, Alexandria, LA
Alexa Alexandria ( La Louisiana )
13 June 1837 Dear Cousin
div.p:
Yours of the 12th May and Cousin Patsy's of a previous date was recd received a few days since announcing to us the untimely death of poor brother Walter , Moore I had heard of it a few days before by Covington Snell & others who I saw at
Alexandria on their way to
Tennessee (all well,. It was distressing to hear of the decease of Walter leaving a young & promising family, but I was not astonished, I frequently mentioned to him that I thought he drank too much but he never appeared to be aware that he was doing so to his injury, he has by imprudence brought on no doubt a premature death, though I hope as I believe is a fact, that he left his family in a situation by frugality to support itself & educate the children, I hope sister Jane will bear it with fortitude, as we should not grieve at the will of providence the debt is one we have all sooner or later to pay.

I am just in from the pine woods this morning left all well but poor little William who has got one of his feet dreadfully burnt, entirely peeled though I am in hopes there will be no deformity Bethiah is fat & John like a guinea pig, Crops generally here are tolerably good some crops of corn are very much injured, mine is seriously
and unless we have rain soon my corn crop must be short I have had but two rains in sixty one days, my Cotten cotton crop is tolerably good though very uneven as the dry weather prevented its coming up at the same time, times have continued very hard, and we can only wish for better as we yet see no prospect of a change, our Banks have all suspended specie payment and can not tell when it will again be resumed, we will be certain of one thing, that is, we shall get nothing for cotten. cotton

I am truly sorry that my ill health prevented me from disposing of John & London at Natchez though John could not be sold for any thing like what you would take for him. I have L. he is a much better hand than I thought he was some time ago though damned decietful deceitful , we have not yet had a single sick negro. Thos Thomas Butler left a few days ago for
Tenn. Tennessee
and was good enough to let us know nothing of it, Bethiah had got some presents to send up by him and tell him she says if he dont don't mind she will tell the secret. We have not heard from Carolina since I left Tenn Tennessee . Write withe news from there & Alabama. Tell Sarah I wrote her some time ago but it seems she did not recieve receive it, but will write her in a few days ( tell her Emily Tumill has married Carson Archinard

Ask the girls if the locust tree is yet alive & how they get on should like to give them a pinch very much (John sings O miss Patsy ding dong da. Thos Thomas House who commited committed the murder in Missippi Mississippi
ben been
acquited acquitted or not.

Shall I ever see you and cousin patsy here or not nothing in the world would give me so much pleasure, the kindness that we recd. received from you & yours under you hospitable roof places us under thousands of obligations and I know of nothing that would gratify us so much as for you to place it in our powers to reciprocate. Give our love to cousin Patsy Sarah Misses Elizabeth & Martha, aunt Butter Jane, Hickory, Julia Ann & the balance of the children and afftey affectionately remember us to all our enquiring friends, my respects to W.L. butler.
May god protect you all & let you live till you wish to die, if that is a thousand years.
div.closer:
Your Friend & relative
Tho Thomas . O. Moore Tell Sarah report is that Doctor Ballard was killed by Mexicans in their taking a much missed belonging to
N New orleans
